NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  slim; not very wide but comparatively long or high 苗条的；细长的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Although her face was quite plain, she had long, slender expressive hands, like a concert pianist.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a place where people have come to settle 新拓居地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Manhattan was the site of the original Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. feeling or showing trust in oneself or one's ability 有信心的；确信的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Michael was confident that he would be enrolled by Harvard University.

NewWords.WordPhrase: abandon an attempt to do sth. 放弃
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He's given up smoking since his illness.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (the C-) God 造物主，上帝
n.  deep strong love 深爱，挚爱
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. People are impressed by her devotion to the cause of education.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. it seems ironic (that) 具有讽刺意味的是
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Ironically the widespread use of antibiotics seems to be causing a lot of unexpected health problems.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. be a symbol of ; stand for 象征，标志   symbol n.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The fall of the Berlin Wall symbolized the end of the Cold War between East and West.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 种族的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Slavery is closely associated with racial prejudice, the belief that one race is superior to another.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (infml) 背叛者；出卖者；背叛；出卖
a. not willing 不愿意的；勉强的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. For months I had been unwilling to face the fact.

NewWords.WordPhrase: speak, work, etc in favor of; support 支持
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You have to be prepared to stand up for the things you believe in.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  famous or important in history 历史上有名或有重要意义的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In his book, Churchill recalls that historic first meeting with Roosevelt.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. place where a building, town, etc. was, is, or will be situated 地方，位置；遗址
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The local government hasn't yet chosen the site for the new skyscraper.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the state of being a slave or the practice of owning slaves 受奴役的状态；奴隶制
n. particular task or duty undertaken by an individual or a group 特殊使命，任务
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some delegates were immediately sent to Israel. Their mission was to negotiate a ceasefire.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  brave; fearless 勇敢的，无畏的
vt. create by means of much hard work（靠艰苦工作）建立
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The two countries agreed to forge closer economic ties.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. operating secretly; under the surface of the ground 秘密的；地下的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His mother took him to Hong Kong where she worked in the underground communist movement.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 网状物；网状组织
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The little boy was frightened by the spider's web in the window.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  set free 解放
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The new Afghan government is trying to liberate its people from poverty with international help.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. give approval or permission for; give authority to 批准；委托
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The central government authorized $200 billion to construct new dams to generate cheap hydro-electric power.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 民权的  civil a. of or relating to the citizens of a country 公民的
n. (usu. pl) 功绩，业绩   vt. 剥削；开发，利用
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The general's wartime exploits were later made into a film and a television series.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  not celebrated in poetry or song; unrecognized（在诗或歌中）未赞颂过的；未获得承认的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. a war won by unsung heroes

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. having the stated firm intention 热中的；坚决的   be intent on (sth./doing sth.) be eager and determined to (do sth.) 热中于，坚决要做
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Working day and night, Janet seems intent on breaking the record in the Guinness Book of Records.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 手枪
n. period of ten years 十年（期）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many countries were involved in Antarctic exploration during the first decade of the 20th century.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 铸造车间；铸造厂
as an additional job or source of income; secretly 作为兼职；秘密地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He makes a little money on the side by cleaning windows in his spare time.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. capturing or being captured 抓捕，捕获
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They live in terror of capture by enemy soldiers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  rather cold and unpleasant 寒飕飕的，冷的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I felt a bit chilly, so I put on a jacket.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. person who is running away 逃亡者
n. person employed to guard a building, esp. at night 看守人；警卫员
ad.  无能为力地  helpless a.
n. person who follows, esp. in order to catch or kill 追赶者，追捕者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We managed to shake off our pursuers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: come near to, esp. in order to attack from several directions; surround 接近；包围
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Hitler committed suicide as Soviet forces were closing in on Berlin.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in a hurry 仓促地；匆忙地
n. 四轮运货马车（或牛车）
a. causing pain; hurting 令人痛苦的；疼痛的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The old photograph brought back painful memories of his childhood.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. 宗教的，宗教上的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The local government wants to increase the amount of religious education in schools.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  firm opinion or belief 坚定的看法或信仰
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The old woman had a firm conviction that there would be a better life after death.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （基督教）贵格会教徒，公谊会教徒
n. “基督教”《圣经》
vt. provide clothes for; put clothes on 供给……衣服；给……穿衣服
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was on her own with two kids to feed and clothe.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  without clothes on 裸体的，赤条条的
vi. come together at a point 会合；集中
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The avenues converge at a central square.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  （铁路、公共汽车等的）终点；（计算机系统的）终端机
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. All staff have terminals attached to the company's main computer.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 地方行政官，执法官
vt. place a (penalty, tax, etc) officially on 把……强加于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The government has made a decision to impose a further tax on wines and spirits.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  prison 监狱
a.  循道宗（信徒）的
vt. put or keep in or as if in prison关押，监禁；束缚
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was imprisoned for two years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. blow with a whip; stroke 鞭打；抽打
with regard to 至于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. As for your request for a free sample , we will send it to you in about ten days.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. not known or identified; not famous 不知道的，陌生的；不著名的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. An unknown disease suddenly attacked the crops in this area.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  cover with a thick dry layer 覆盖
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His shoes were caked with mud.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 粉；粉末
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We wash clothes with soap powder.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. （有带）女帽
n. 面纱；面罩
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In many Muslim countries, the women wear veils.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. take from one place to another in a vehicle 运输，运送
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Reducing the costs of transporting natural resources to production sites is one of the key factors in economic competition.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a, n.  (person) who has run away 逃跑的（人）
vt. make look or sound different from normal; give a false appearance 假扮，伪装
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She disguised herself as a man so she could fight on the battlefield.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. ceremony of burying dead people 葬礼，丧礼
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His funeral will be on Thursday at the nearby cathedral.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 行列，队伍
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They watched the procession go past.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. end the existence of (a custom, system, etc) 废除（法律、习惯等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Slavery was not finally abolished in the British Empire until 1833.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. never explored or cultivated 未开发的   n. person, esp. a girl or woman, who has never had sex 处女   on a small/ large scale 小（大）规模地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Within 40 years there will be no virgin forest left.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. cruelly or unkindly 严厉地，苛刻地   harsh a.
accept an unsatisfactory situation cheerfully and try to manage as well as you can 尽量利用，充分利用
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I know it's cold and raining but we're here now, so let's just make the best of it.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  勤奋的  diligently ad.  showing care and effort in one's work or duties 勤奋地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The boy is more diligent than anybody else.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  force; get or bring about by force 强迫；强求
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In the past children were frequently compelled to work from an early age.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 种植园
n. saving or being saved from danger, evil, etc. 拯救，解救
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Government loans have been the salvation of several shaky business companies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: threatened by the possibility of loss, failure, etc; in danger 有危险；冒风险
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It is reported that some areas in the west are at high risk of desertification（沙漠化）.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in the opinion of 在（某人）看来
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In the eyes of his students, Richard is a sensible and reliable teacher.

NewWords.WordPhrase: appear like; be accepted or looked upon as 被看作；被当作
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He speaks American English well enough to pass for an American.
